p: As displayed above, the fruit juice of Momordica charantia herb was determined to be an antioxidant composition because of the radical scavenging effect of the butanol fraction from M. charantia extract [ 131]. As the same result, in 2014, Tsai TH et al. demonstrated antioxidant activity and cell-protective activity of M. charantia extract because this herb extract could scavenge several free radicals [ 132]. The antidiabetic action of Momordica charantia has been elucidated through this mechanism. The efficacy of some Indian ayurvedic plant extracts, including Momordica charantia, Eugenia jambolana ( Figure 14), Tinospora cordifolia and Mucuna pruriens ( Figure 15) was investigated for the prevention of diabetic cataract in vivo. The results showed that Momordica charantia and Eugenia jambolana had better protective activity in the development of diabetic cataract as compared to Tinospora cordifolia and Mucuna pruriens [ 133].
